title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.6.22 | 17-11-2021
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiran Dhasya Gyanan Janishalakaya
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: O virtuous one, you have only once seen my person and this is just to increase your desire for me.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam (SB 1.6.22) and explains the context of Lord's words to Narada Muni after he lost sight of the Lord in meditation.

segments.key_quote: Because till one is completely purified in the heart, one cannot actually see the Lord, the spiritual form of the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the reason why the Lord gave only a brief darshan to Narada, emphasizing the importance of purification and increasing the desire to see and associate with the Lord.

segments.key_quote: A living being cannot be vacant of desires.
segments.summary: The speaker quotes Srila Prabhupada, explaining that spiritual life doesn't mean becoming desireless, but rather purifying or replacing material desires with spiritual desires, focusing on pleasing the Lord instead of the senses.

segments.key_quote: Thinking for the service of the Lord itself is spiritual.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to explain Prabhupada's teachings, highlighting that living beings must have desires and that entanglement arises from material thinking, feeling, and willing, while devotional service frees one from entanglement by focusing on the Lord's service.

segments.key_quote: The more a person is engaged in the transcendental loving service of the Lord, the more he acquires a hankering for it.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the nature of devotional service, explaining that even a small beginning, like chanting Hare Krishna, can lead to an increased hankering for the Lord and that guidance from experienced devotees is essential.

segments.key_quote: This is spiritual sound this is transcendental it is full of spiritual nector.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts chanting Hare Krishna with repeating a material sound, like 'coca-cola', explaining that the transcendental nature of the holy name prevents boredom and increases the desire to chant.

segments.key_quote: Material service has satiation... Whereas spiritual service of the lord has neither satiation nor end.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the concept of satiation in material activities using the analogy of eating chocolate, contrasting it with the eternal and non-satiating nature of spiritual service to the Lord.

segments.key_quote: Spiritual service is on the spiritual platform therefore it is eternal.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates the eternal nature of spiritual service, emphasizing that it continues beyond the material body and that devotional service, like chanting Hare Krishna, has no satiation.

segments.key_quote: Anybody engaged in devotional service is actually seeing the lord through the service because the lord and his devotional service are identical.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by explaining that engaging in devotional service is equivalent to seeing the Lord, as the Lord and His service are identical, and encourages sincere devotees to continue their service for purification and perfection.
